Introduction.3: This is a project  management simulation. The role of the user as project manager is to assign  employees to the appropriate projects and locations based on a set of information.

Tutorial.1: In the following messages, an example will be described which will demonstrate how to use the information grid.
Tutorial.2: Example Scenario: Four people will each be given a gift. No two people can receive the same gift and one person cannot get more than one gift
Tutorial.3: The grid is to look like this:
Tutorial.4: In this example, James does not like videogames. This option will be eliminated by marking it with an X (click once on the corresponding box).
Tutorial.5: The grid is to look like this:
Tutorial.6: In this example, Ali will receive the skateboard. User will select this option by marking it with an O (click twice on the corresponding box).
Tutorial.7: The grid is to look like this:
Tutorial.8: Other combinations will need to be eliminated based on previous decisions. Since Ali will be given the skateboard (and no one else can have the same gift), the skateboard options should be eliminated for everyone else. User needs to place X's for the skateboard options for everyone else and for all the other gift options for Ali.
Tutorial.9: The grid is to look like this:
Tutorial.10: Thus, the information grid is used to note which combinations have been eliminated (X) or selected (O).
Tutorial.11: The grid should only be marked if it is certain that an option should be eliminated or selected. To remove a marking, click on the selected box a third time.

Introduction.4: Welcome to the project management simulator. Your role as the project manager is to assign your employees to the appropriate projects and locations based on a set of information.

Tutorial.1: I'm here to help by providing the information that you need to make the right decision.
Tutorial.2: In order to help you understand how to complete the assignment,.let's go over how to use the information grid. I'll use a running example to teach you how to use the information grid.
Tutorial.3: Imagine you are deciding which gift to give to four of your friends. Each gift should be special so no two people can receive the same gift. Also, you only have one of each item so each person cannot get more than one gift.
Tutorial.4: The grid should look like this:
Tutorial.5: In this example, let's say James does not like videogames so you shouldn't get him any. Please eliminate this option by marking it with an X (click once on the corresponding box).
Tutorial.6: The grid should look like this:
Tutorial.7: You also know that Ali really enjoys skating so you should get him a skateboard. Please select this option by marking it with an O (click twice on the corresponding box).
Tutorial.8: The grid should look like this:
Tutorial.9: You can go ahead and eliminate other options based on previous decisions. Since Ali will be given the skateboard (and no one else can have the same gift), the skateboard options should be eliminated for everyone else. Please place X's for the skateboard options for everyone else and for all the other gift options for Ali.
Tutorial.10: The grid should look like this:
Tutorial.11: As you can see, the information grid is used to note which combinations you have eliminated (X) or selected (O).
Tutorial.12: And please be careful - only mark the grid if you're certain that an option should be eliminated or selected. If you want to remove a marking, click on the selected box a third time.
Tutorial.13: Okay, [Name]! That concludes the basic training on how to use the grid. I think you're ready for the task.
